name: PlanDefinition_Care and treatment clinical visit
title: PlanDefinition - Care and treatment clinical visit
description: To initiate ART and to provide HIV care, treatment and integrated health services

action.title: Care and treatment clinical visit business process
action.description: To initiate ART and to provide HIV care, treatment and integrated health services

action.title: Determine reason for visit
action.description: Search for client details in the system and determine reason for visit

action.title: Take vital signs
action.description: Also record weight, height, etc. For children, weight will be needed to determine dosage and to check for malnutrition.

action.title: Check for signs of serious illness
action.description: Any person who has signs of seriously illness should be referred to the appropriate higher-lever facility for management

action.title: Screen for TB
action.description: Adults and adolescents living with HIV should be screened for TB according to a clinical algorithm

action.title: Seriously ill?
action.description: Any person who has signs of serious illness should be referred to the appropriate higher-lever facility for management or receive emergency care, depending on availability and policies.

action.title: Capture or update client history
action.description: Discuss history with client and review available records. History-taking should include partner’s HIV status and whether the partner is virally suppressed on ART

action.title: First time initiating treatment?
action.description: This step checks whether the client is naïve to ART

action.title: Counsel returning clients
action.description: Adherence, such as whether client is picking up meds and/or has any barriers to adherence to their treatment(s), if so, set plan for adherence support

action.title: Retest for HIV using testing algorithm
action.description: WHO recommends that all programmes retest people diagnosed with HIV prior to initiating lifelong ART

action.title: Determine recommended screenings and tests
action.description: HIV.D12.DT Determine recommended screenings and tests

action.title: Examine client
action.description: Examine the client clinically, with a physical exam

action.title: Prevent, screen and manage comorbidities and coinfections
action.description: With ART, HIV is a chronic disease requiring lifetime care. WHO guidelines cover information on common and important concomitant conditions among people living with HIV, including: co-trimoxazole prophylaxis; the diagnosis, prevention and treatment of TB, viral hepatitis, malaria, sexually transmitted infections, cervical cancer prevention, nutrition, vaccinations, mental health and substance use

action.title: Determine clinical stage of HIV
action.description: HIV.D15.DT Determine WHO clinical stage of HIV

action.title: Perform other screenings
action.description: Conduct screenings based on recommendations and priorities and depending on the diagnostics that are available.

action.title: Check for signs of treatment failure
action.description: Review new diagnostic results

action.title: Diagnostics
action.description: Viral load should be tested routinely for early warning of virological failure and monitored if clinical or virological failure are suspected

action.title: Determine regimen and treatment options
action.description: For continuing care, check the dosage and need for readjustment or whether treatment failure is suspected.

action.title: Make informed decision on treatment
action.description: Even if client is eligible to start ART, the choice to accept or decline ART ultimately lies with the person or his or her caregiver, and if the decision is to defer initiation, ART can be offered again at subsequent visits

action.title: Prescribe
action.description: The scripting period should cover the period until the next clinical consultation (not until the following ART refill visit).

action.title: Counsel
action.description: Counsel clients on adherence.

action.title: Laboratory diagnostics needed
action.description: Additional testing or specimen collection may be needed and may happen after the visit
